WEEKDAYS AT MOMâ€™S - KIDS PROTOCOL

For: Willow (Age 6) and Sebastian (Age 9)
When: Monday 6:00 PM â†’ Friday 4:00 PM (When Dad is in Solo Mode)
Purpose: Help you have a good week even when Dad canâ€™t be there. Youâ€™ve got tools to help yourself.

ğŸ“„ HOW TO USE THIS CHECKLIST

Best Way: Print this page! Then you can:

  • âœ… Check off boxes with a pencil each day
  • âœ… Keep it in your backpack or room
  • âœ… Look at it when you need help or feel stuck
  • âœ… Bring it to Dadâ€™s on Friday to show what you did

Mom Can Help Too: Ask Mom to help you with this checklist if you need it!

On Computer: The checkboxes work on the website too, but they reset when you close the page. Printing is better!

ğŸ  WHAT THIS WEEK LOOKS LIKE

Monday-Friday at Momâ€™s

  • You go to school
  • You come home to Momâ€™s house
  • You do homework
  • You have dinner
  • You have evening time
  • You go to bed
  • You wake up and do it again

Dadâ€™s Promise

Even though Dad isnâ€™t there during the week, Dad is still your dad. Dad still loves you. Dad still thinks about you every single day.

This paper is like having a little piece of Dadâ€™s help with you at Momâ€™s house.

ğŸ“‹ YOUR WEEKDAY CHECKLIST (Do These Every Day)

Morning Checklist (Before School)

If mornings are hard: Do one thing at a time. Donâ€™t think about the whole list.

After School Checklist

Evening Checklist

ğŸ“š HOMEWORK HELPER (When Homework Feels Hard)

Step-by-Step Homework Plan

  1. Find a quiet spot - Ask Mom for a place with no TV
  2. Get supplies - Pencil, paper, books, whatever you need
  3. Set a timer - Start with 15 minutes
  4. Work until timer beeps - Try your best
  5. Take a 5-minute break - Stand up, stretch, get water
  6. Do another 15 minutes - If you have more work
  7. Done! - Put homework in backpack

When Homework Feels Impossible

Try these tricks:

  • Read the directions twice - Sometimes the second time makes sense
  • Do the easy parts first - Skip the hard ones for now
  • Ask Mom for help - She might know (or can look it up)
  • Call or text Dad - If Mom says itâ€™s okay, Dad can help over the phone
  • Write a note to the teacher - â€œI tried but didnâ€™t understandâ€ is honest
  • Do your best - Thatâ€™s all Dad asks

If You Forget Homework at School

Itâ€™s okay. It happens. Tell your teacher in the morning. Donâ€™t lie about it.

ğŸ¨ THINGS TO DO WHEN YOU'RE BORED (Without a Tablet)

If You Only Have Paper and Pencil

  1. Draw - Anything! Animals, houses, patterns, scribbles
  2. Write a story - Make up anything you want
  3. Make a list - Favorite foods, animals, colors, anything
  4. Draw Dad a picture - Keep it to give him on Friday
  5. Make a paper airplane - See how far it flies
  6. Play tic-tac-toe - By yourself (try to win!)
  7. Trace your hand - Make it into a turkey or monster
  8. Make a paper fortune teller - Fold and write silly fortunes

If You Have Some Toys at Momâ€™s

  1. Build with what you have - Blocks, boxes, pillows
  2. Stuffed animal adventures - Make up stories with them
  3. Pretend play - Youâ€™re a teacher, chef, astronaut, anything
  4. Organize your toys - Sort by color, size, type
  5. Make a fort - Use blankets and pillows (ask Mom first)

Things You Can Do Alone

  1. Read any book - Even if youâ€™ve read it before
  2. Look out the window - Watch birds, cars, clouds
  3. Sing songs - Make up your own
  4. Practice writing your name - Make it fancy
  5. Count things - How many steps to your room? How many toys?
  6. Think about the weekend - Plan what you want to do at Dadâ€™s

Things to Ask Mom to Do

  1. Go outside - Even just the backyard
  2. Help cook dinner - Kids can help!
  3. Play a game - Cards, board game, anything
  4. Take a walk - Around the block
  5. Do a puzzle - If she has one
  6. Ask her to read to you - Even if you can read yourself

ğŸ˜° WHEN YOU FEEL SAD, MAD, OR SCARED

Big Feelings Are Normal

At Momâ€™s house, you might feel:

  • Sad - You miss Dad, you miss your stuff, you miss the weekend
  • Mad - You donâ€™t want to be at two houses
  • Bored - You donâ€™t have your LEGOs or your room at Dadâ€™s
  • Lonely - You wish someone would play with you
  • Worried - About school, friends, Mom and Dad, lots of things

ALL OF THESE ARE OKAY. Youâ€™re not bad for feeling this way.

What You Can Do Right Now (By Yourself)

1. Breathing Exercise

  • Breathe in slowly (count to 4)
  • Hold it (count to 4)
  • Breathe out slowly (count to 4)
  • Do this 3 times
  • You might feel a little calmer

2. Tell Your Stuffed Animal

  • Find any stuffed animal or toy
  • Tell it how you feel
  • Itâ€™s okay if you cry
  • The toy wonâ€™t judge you

3. Draw Your Feelings

  • Get paper and crayons/pencil
  • Draw how you feel (doesnâ€™t have to look like anything)
  • Mad might be scribbles, sad might be rain
  • You can rip it up after if you want

4. Count Things

  • Count backward from 100 (or as high as you can)
  • Count all the things you can see that are blue
  • Count your breaths
  • This gives your brain something else to do

5. Move Your Body

  • Do 10 jumping jacks
  • Run in place for 30 seconds
  • Dance to a song in your head
  • Shake your arms and legs
  • Movement helps big feelings

What to Say to Mom

If you need to talk to Mom about feelings:

  • â€œI feel sadâ€
  • â€œI miss Dadâ€
  • â€œI need a hugâ€
  • â€œCan I call Dad?â€
  • â€œI donâ€™t want to talk about it, but Iâ€™m upsetâ€

Mom loves you too. She wants to help even if she doesnâ€™t know how.

ğŸ“ CONNECTING WITH DAD DURING THE WEEK

You Can Talk to Dad

Even though Dad canâ€™t be there, you can still connect:

Text Messages (Mom Can Help You)

  • Send Dad a text: â€œHi Dad I miss youâ€
  • Tell Dad about your day: â€œWe learned about space todayâ€
  • Ask Dad a question: â€œWhatâ€™s for dinner this weekend?â€
  • Send a picture: Draw something and have Mom take a photo

Phone Calls

  • Best times to call Dad:
    • After school (4:00-5:00 PM) - Dad is on his break
    • After dinner (7:00-8:00 PM) - Dad is done working
    • Bedtime (8:00 PM) - Dad always has time to say goodnight

Ask Mom: â€œCan I call Dad?â€ She should say yes.

If Mom Says No or Forgets

  • Itâ€™s not your fault
  • Mom is doing her best
  • Youâ€™ll see Dad on Friday
  • Dad knows you love him even if you canâ€™t call

What to Talk to Dad About

  • How school went
  • Something funny that happened
  • A problem youâ€™re having
  • How youâ€™re feeling
  • What you want to do this weekend
  • Nothing at all - just hear his voice

You can call for any reason. Dad wants to hear from you.

ğŸ›ï¸ BEDTIME WHEN DAD ISN'T THERE

Your Bedtime Routine at Momâ€™s

If You Have Trouble Sleeping

Things That Might Help:

  1. Think About Friday - Picture Dad picking you up
  2. Remember a Fun Time - Think about last weekend
  3. Count Backward - From 100 or as high as you can
  4. The Alphabets Game - Name an animal for each letter (Alligator, Bear, Catâ€¦)
  5. Hug Your Stuffed Animal - Pretend itâ€™s a hug from Dad
  6. Say This to Yourself:
    • â€œI am safeâ€
    • â€œMom is hereâ€
    • â€œI will see Dad soonâ€
    • â€œTomorrow will be okayâ€

Pretend Dad Is Saying Goodnight

Close your eyes and imagine Dad is there saying:

  • â€œI love youâ€
  • â€œYouâ€™re safeâ€
  • â€œYouâ€™re doing greatâ€
  • â€œIâ€™m proud of youâ€
  • â€œIâ€™ll see you soonâ€
  • â€œSleep well, kiddoâ€

Dad is thinking these things every single night, even if he canâ€™t say them in person.

ğŸ’ SCHOOL SURVIVAL GUIDE

If School Is Hard

  1. Ask your teacher for help - Thatâ€™s their job
  2. Sit in the front - Itâ€™s easier to pay attention
  3. Be honest - â€œI donâ€™t understandâ€ is a good thing to say
  4. Take breaks - Ask for bathroom break if you need a minute
  5. Do your best - Nobodyâ€™s perfect

If Someone Is Mean to You

  1. Walk away - You donâ€™t have to listen to mean people
  2. Tell a teacher - They need to know
  3. Tell Mom - She can help
  4. Tell Dad on Friday - Dad will help figure it out
  5. Remember: Their meanness is about them, not you

If You Get in Trouble

  1. Tell the truth - Donâ€™t lie to make it better
  2. Accept the consequence - Say â€œokayâ€ and move on
  3. Tell Mom - Even if youâ€™re scared to
  4. Tell Dad - Dad wonâ€™t be mad at you for being honest
  5. Learn from it - Try not to do it again

Youâ€™re going to make mistakes. Thatâ€™s how kids learn.

ğŸ½ï¸ EATING AT MOM'S HOUSE

If Mom Makes Something You Donâ€™t Like

  • Try one bite (just one!)
  • If you really canâ€™t eat it, say politely: â€œMay I have something else?â€
  • If Mom says no, eat what you can
  • You wonâ€™t starve - breakfast comes tomorrow
  • Tell Dad about it Friday (maybe he can help pack snacks for you)

If Youâ€™re Still Hungry

  • Ask Mom: â€œMay I have a snack?â€
  • Suggestions: Apple, crackers, cheese, anything simple
  • Itâ€™s okay to be hungry - growing kids get hungry!

Foods That Are Usually at Every House

  • Bread (make toast)
  • Cereal
  • Fruit (usually apples or bananas)
  • Crackers
  • Peanut butter (if youâ€™re not allergic)

If thereâ€™s really no food, tell Dad. Dad can help.

ğŸ—“ï¸ KEEPING TRACK OF DAYS

How Many Days Until Dad?

Monday: 4 more days (almost a whole week)
Tuesday: 3 more days (youâ€™re getting close!)
Wednesday: 2 more days (middle of the week!)
Thursday: 1 more day (tomorrow is Friday!)
Friday: TODAY! Dad picks you up after school! ğŸ‰

Make a Paper Chain

  1. Get 4 strips of paper (Mom can help cut them)
  2. Write one day on each: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday
  3. Connect them in a chain (tape or staple)
  4. Each morning, tear off one link
  5. When the chain is gone, itâ€™s Friday!

Or Draw It

Draw 4 boxes in a row. Each night before bed, color one in. When all 4 are colored, you see Dad tomorrow!

ğŸ’ª YOU ARE STRONGER THAN YOU THINK

Things You Can Do Without Dad

  • Get through a whole school day
  • Do your homework (mostly)
  • Be kind to others
  • Take care of yourself
  • Help Mom (if she needs it)
  • Handle your big feelings
  • Wake up and try again the next day

Things to Remember

  1. This is temporary - You will see Dad again
  2. You are loved - By Dad, by Mom, by people who care
  3. Youâ€™re doing great - Even when it doesnâ€™t feel like it
  4. Itâ€™s okay to struggle - This IS hard
  5. Friday always comes - Every week, without fail

ğŸ“ WEEKLY REFLECTION (Answer on Friday Afternoon)

Before Dad picks you up, think about this week:

ğŸš¨ EMERGENCY SITUATIONS

If Something Really Bad Happens

  • Someone is hurt: Tell Mom or call 911
  • You feel unsafe: Tell a teacher, call Dad, call 911
  • Youâ€™re alone and scared: Call Mom, call Dad, call 911
  • Someone touches you wrong: Tell Mom, tell Dad, tell a teacher immediately

Dadâ€™s Phone Number

You can ALWAYS call Dad. Anytime. Day or night. Even if Mom says no.

If Mom wonâ€™t let you use the phone and you need Dad:

  • Tell a teacher at school
  • Ask a trusted adult to help
  • Remember: You see Dad on Friday no matter what

ğŸ’™ DAD'S SPECIAL MESSAGE TO YOU

Dear [Daughter] and [Son],

I know this week is hard. I know you miss me. I miss you too - SO MUCH.

Every day while youâ€™re at Momâ€™s, I think about you. I wonder how school went. I wonder if youâ€™re happy or sad. I wonder if youâ€™re sleeping okay. I wonder what youâ€™re doing right now.

I wish I could be there for dinner. I wish I could help with homework. I wish I could read you a bedtime story. I wish I could hug you whenever you need it.

But I canâ€™t be there Monday through Friday. And thatâ€™s really hard. For you AND for me.

So I made this guide to be like a little piece of me you can carry around. When you read it, remember:

I am still your dad. Every single day. Even when Iâ€™m not there.

When you do your homework, Iâ€™m proud of you.
When youâ€™re kind to someone, Iâ€™m proud of you.
When you cry because you miss me, Iâ€™m proud of you for having feelings.
When you make mistakes, Iâ€™m proud of you for being human.
When you get through the day, Iâ€™m proud of you for being strong.

You donâ€™t have to be perfect. You donâ€™t have to be happy all the time. You just have to make it to Friday, and Iâ€™ll be there.

I promise I will always come get you on Friday. Always.

I love you bigger than the whole sky.

Love,
Dad ğŸ’™

âœ… FRIDAY CHECKLIST (The Best Day!)

When Dad Picks You Up

ğŸ—“ï¸ KEEPING TRACK OF DAYS

How Many Days Until Dad?

Monday: 4 more days (almost a whole week)
Tuesday: 3 more days (youâ€™re getting close!)
Wednesday: 2 more days (middle of the week!)
Thursday: 1 more day (tomorrow is Friday!)
Friday: TODAY! Dad picks you up after school! ğŸ‰

Make a Paper Chain

  1. Get 4 strips of paper (Mom can help cut them)
  2. Write one day on each: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday
  3. Connect them in a chain (tape or staple)
  4. Each morning, tear off one link
  5. When the chain is gone, itâ€™s Friday!

Or Draw It

Draw 4 boxes in a row. Each night before bed, color one in. When all 4 are colored, you see Dad tomorrow!
